title: How to Eat Well at a Convention

steps.headline: Drink water.
steps.description: Get a nice stainless steel water bottle. Fill it every couple of hours.

steps.headline: Find the food sources!
steps.description: Not just the dealer's room; find a convention suite, a snack table or any rooms with particularly charitable convention-goers. Try to find a fridge if you're bringing your own food. Mark it on your maps.

steps.headline: Bring your own food.-- Enough to last a weekend.
steps.description: Peanut butter and crackers are a great snack and bringing fruits or vegetables that do not bruise easily (oranges, apples, carrots) will go a long way toward providing healthy food.

steps.headline: Plan a budget for purchasing food.
steps.description: This isn't a major step, you just need to determine if you'll be leaving the con for a real meal. Don't spend more than nine dollars a day on snack food or you'll not only go over budget, you'll ingest an unhealthy amount of sugar and fat before the convention is over.

steps.headline: Find noodles, a veggie tray and/or fresh fruit somewhere.
steps.description: Take it with you if you can.

steps.headline: Stay sanitary.
steps.description: Wash your hands as often as possible (definitely after using the bathrooms, which are usually filthy). Keep a travel bottle of hand sanitizer with you and use it prior to handling any food on the go.

steps.headline: If you're feeling upset or sleepless, make yourself some tea.
steps.description: If you don't like tea or it's too hot, wait until it has cooled and down it in one gulp. Certain teas help calm you, notably chamomile tea.

steps.headline: Indulge every once in a while.
steps.description: Free candy and sweets are OK, just not for every meal.
